comment: Thank you so so much everyone for watching this series! If you'd like to keep up with Carrie Anne be sure to subscribe to her youtube channel "Geek Gurl Dairies" and follow her on twitter @MissPhilbin. She's doing so much awesome work teaching the world about computer science. If you'd like more great computer science content you should really check out youtube channel "Computerphile". And if you want to try some coding yourself you've gotta try some of the amazing programming courses at Khanacademy.org! I hope to see many of you on our first MATH course, Crash Course Statistics, in January! -brandon

The problem isn't that technological change is causing unemployment. It's that capitalism as a system cannot cope with massive increases in efficiency and productivity without causing major problems that need to be patched in precarious ways. The only way to maximize automation is to replace capitalism with a system where power does not funnel to the top, workers have democratic control over the economy, and the technological advancements we make allow us all collectively to work less and have more free time.

This will seem lame but I totally started crying upon starting this last video.   I love Comptuer Science (especially so having a background in Philosophy). My entire adult life now 27 I have had questions about the ins and outs of the computer world but have been left frustrated by the lack of reliable and clear answers.   Thanks to this program, I now see the light!   I owe you an immense debt of gratitude. This planet owes you an immense debt of gratitude.   Oh yeah, the crying bit.. I cried because I was struck with a deep feeling I'd never recognized before; a toxic belief. I was convinced that I had been abandoned or perhaps, counted out in my pursuit of CS. I'm too poor to go bootstrap a basic CS degree and having just started a family I certainly didn't feel I'd have time to catch up. I cried because your team didn't just dabble in the subject but followed it through to a responsible end. Even as viewer count declined over the course of the series you finished a good work and allowed guys like me to catch up. It felt like you did it for me, from compassion, and it moved me deeply.   I'll close by scaling my love letter up just one more layer of abstraction:  XOXO TYSM WD

Why do we even care what the low wage labor workers think about job automation.  It's not like that add any real value to the world. Great series.   However, I think the assumption that "history shows we've dealt with this fine" is extremely flawed. We have almost no history to base this on. Technology only started dramatically moving people away from mostly farming a few centuries ago. Technology freed us from needing to use our bodies to being able to use our minds- humans weren't obsolete because we continued to, in mass quantities, still have something to contribute with our minds. However as more jobs are automated, the need for physical labor continues to decline, as does mental labor. The space for humans to give more shrinks. This also doesn't address the fact that as the automation increases in speed, that quick little "short term economic problem" will be far more disruptive. 20%+ Unemployment in the U.S. Depression was country-crippling; we don't just need to start worrying when we start eliminating 60% of jobs  as mentioned. If we haven't fundamentally shifted in a completely unknowable (or at the least, exceptional by modern standards) way very soon, we're going to see those effects firsthand.   As mentioned in CGP Grey's Humans Need Not Apply,  horses didn't find new jobs because the Model-T "freed them up to do other things". Horses become un-employable because they had nothing left to give the economy. Pretending that humans are somehow different and will be able to, en masse, find infinite forms of work because of our infinitely complex brains, is dangerously optimistic.

The whole 'uploading your consciousness' thing confuses me.  Even if we had computers capable of that, and I uploaded an exact copy of my brain today, my actual consciousness will still die with my body, and the only thing that lives on would be a copy from the time I uploaded it.  That's not immortality.  From my perspective I will still die eventually and my consciousness will end.  I don't get to magically switch to the one that is in the computer.  I also have a hard time seeing how robots will be able to maintain themselves in, for example, assembly line maintenance roles.  You would need a robot with all the troubleshooting and diagnostic capabilities to diagnose and troubleshoot electrical and mechanical problems as well as the dexterity and mobility of a human, that sometimes needs to climb, crawl, ect to get into hard to reach places to perform this kind of troubleshooting and maintenance.  It's foolish to say something will NEVER happen, but right now I can't imagine it happening in this century at least.  That is assuming we solve some of the engineering issues like power supplies and bi-pedal motion (or some other kind of motion that would allow a robot to traverse stairs, ladders, crawl spaces and all sorts of uneven terrain).
Why would a logic machine encourage unsustainable growth of a species?  It would NEED to "prune the tree's" every once in awhile.

Serious question: what do you think will happen if we allow capitalists to continue accumulating wealth/property while human labor becomes less and less necessary?  A complete economic collapse that forces us to rebuild our societal structure?  A violent revolution?  Would a revolution even be possible when the military is fully automated?  I'm hoping for some kind of egalitarian post-scarcity society, but I'm worried that it will be a difficult road to get there.

>"I'm hoping for some kind of egalitarian post-scarcity society, but I'm worried that it will be a difficult road to get there"   It's not just difficult, it's absolutely impossible and foolishly naive under capitalism. If technology continues to be developed with an underlying subtext of profit over diminishing human suffering, human suffering will continue to worsen and people will become increasingly oppressed to the point where there could be an actual post scarcity economy for exactly 1% of humans alive, while the other 99% live in a wasteland of inaccessibility and can't do a damn thing about it due to automation having destroyed any of their chances at learning skills.

Yes, of course this hypothetical future utopia would not be capitalistic.  I just meant that I hope we are able to get there, not that it would be the result of capitalism.  My thought process was that a worst case scenario would be capitalism persists as long as possible until it is no longer possible to sustain, at which point we have to rebuild society from the ground up.  That is what I meant by "a difficult road to get there".  If I'm understanding you correctly, capitalism is not necessarily doomed to failure and the scenario you described could persist indefinitely if we allow it to get to that point... that is a very scary thought.

I don't think it won't happen somehow, and I'm hopeful as well that capitalism never reaches that point, but at the same time sad and resigned to the fact I will probably never live to see the singularity. That said though, I do feel somewhat thrilled at being able to exist at such a point in history to where humanity is beginning to see glimpses of it, and I may actually get to participate in your "difficult road". Time will only tell HOW difficult.

I wouldn't recommend coding as a career if you're just now getting into the world of work. AIs will soon be doing most of the coding faster and more accurately than a human can. Instead, study AI architecture, interface design and aesthetics.  While it will soon be common to say to an AI, "Write a program to do X, Y, and Z," deciding what tasks should be prioritized and what goals should be worked toward will be human tasks for a generation or two.  We don't write in machine code anymore, and third and fourth level languages will soon be obsolete as well.  As the video says, 60% of jobs are squarely in the crosshairs of automation.  And those who say we'll get more leisure time and the benefits of increased productivity will be spread throughout society need to forget about computers and read some economic history.

Obviously You have never repaired a steam turbine. I just performed a triptest on a turbine, witch is not complicated for a human, but I can imagine huge problems for automation. Steam clouds and discoloring on the shaft interfering with the measurements. A stuck trip pen due to a misalignment of the tripdisc on the shaft. But there was no dimple, so we had to drill a dimple. reassemble everything and perform another triptest and adjust the spring on the trip bolt.
